column15: Clarity
column16: Perceived Malt Aroma & Flavor
column17: Perceived Hop Aroma & Flavor
column19: Fermentation Characteristics
column21: Additional notes

column15: Appearance should be clear. Chill haze should not be present
column16: A malty sweet aroma and flavor should be present at low levels. Bready or light biscuity attributes may be present.
column17: Hop aroma and ﬂavor is moderate and pronounced, derived from late hopping (not dry hopping) with noble-type hops.
column19: Fruity-ester and DMS should not be present. These are well attenuated beers.
column21: The head should be dense, pure white and persistent.

column15: Appearance should be clear. Chill haze should not be present
column16: A slightly sweet and toasted, biscuity, bready malt aroma and ﬂavor is present.
column17: Medium-low to medium, derived from late kettle hopping with noble-type hops.
column19: Very low levels of diacetyl, if present, are characteristic of this style and may accent malt character. Low levels of sulfur compounds may be present. DMS should not be present.
column21: The head should be dense.

column15: Appearance should be clear. Chill haze should not be present
column16: Malt aroma and ﬂavor are pronounced. Low levels of yeast-produced sulfur aromas and ﬂavors may be present. Malt character is sometimes bready and suggestive of lightly toasted malted barley. There should be no caramel character.
column17: Hop aroma is not present to low. Hop ﬂavor is very low to low, derived from noble-type hops.
column18: Low, derived from European noble-type hops.
column19: Fruity esters, DMS and diacetyl should not be present. A very low level of sulfur attributes may be present in balance with other attributes.
column21: Many beer brands known as Austrian-Style Maerzen are nearly indistinguishable from Munich-Style Helles and are appropriately categorized here.

column15: Appearance should be clear. Chill haze should not be present
column16: Sweet malt character should be low and should not be caramelly
column17: Very low to low, derived from noble-type hops.
column19: Fruity esters and diacetyl should not be present.
column21: Traditionally, German-style Export beers were brewed to higher gravity/higher alcohol than domestic beers to promote longer shelf-life in export markets.

column15: Appearance should be clear. Chill haze should not be present
column16: Characterized by malty aroma and light malt sweetness, which should have a lightly toasted malt character.
column17: Very low to low, derived from noble-type hops.
column18: Low to medium-low, clean and crisp.
column19: DMS, diacetyl, and fruity esters should not be present.

column15: Clear to slightly hazy for unfiltered versions. Chill haze should not be present.
column16: Light toasted malt aroma and malt sweetness is typical. Light caramel or biscuit character may be present.
column17: Low to medium-low, with attributes typical of noble-type hops.
column18: Low to medium-low, producing a clean finish.
column19: DMS, diacetyl, fruity esters and phenolic attributes should not be present.

column15: Appearance should be clear. Chill haze should not be present
column16: Bready or biscuity malt aroma and flavor should be present. Sweet maltiness is medium-low to medium and leads to a muted clean hop bitterness. Malt ﬂavors should be of light toast rather than strong caramel. Low level caramel character is acceptable.
column17: Low with attributes typical of noble hop varieties
column19: Fruity esters and diacetyl should not be present

column15: Appearance should be clear. Chill haze should not be present
column16: Clean, sweet, bready malt profile is low to medium-low
column17: Very low to low
column18: Very low to low and in balance with low sweet maltiness
column19: Fruity esters and diacetyl should not be present
column21: Traditional Oktoberfest beers were brewed to original gravity at or above 13 ºPlato. Today, some examples are brewed to a lower original gravity.

column15: Appearance should be clear. Chill haze should not be present
column16: Malt character is low to medium, with chocolate, roast, bread or biscuit aromas and flavors contributed by using dark Munich malt or other specialty malts.
column17: Very low to low, with attributes typical of noble-type hops.
column19: Fruity esters and diacetyl should not be present
column21: Dunkels do not offer an overly sweet impression, but rather a balance between malt and dark malt sweetness and hop character.

column14: Very dark brown to black, with a pale-colored head.
column15: Beer color may be too dark to perceive. When clarity is perceivable, chill haze should not be present.
column16: Medium malt aroma displays a mild roasted malt character. Malt sweetness is low to medium and displays a mild roasted malt character without bitterness.
column17: Hop aroma and ﬂavor is very low to low, derived from noble-type hops.
column19: Fruity esters and diacetyl should not be present.

column15: Appearance should be clear. Chill haze should not be present
column16: Low to medium
column17: Low to medium
column19: Fruity esters and diacetyl should not be present. Very low levels of sulfur-related compounds are acceptable.

column15: Appearance should be clear. Chill haze should not be present
column16: Malt character is prominent with malt aromas suggesting lightly toasted sweet malted barley. Smoke beechwood character ranges from very low to medium. Smoky aroma should be not harshly phenolic. Sulfur may be present at low levels. There should be no caramel character. Smoke ﬂavor may create a perception of mild sweetness.
column17: Hop aroma and ﬂavor is very low to low, derived from noble-type hops.
column19: Fruity esters and diacetyl should not be present. Very low levels of sulfur-related compounds are acceptable.

column15: Appearance should be clear. Chill haze should not be present
column16: Sweet toasted malt aroma should be present. Medium-low to medium toasted malt sweetness should be present. Aroma and flavor of smoked beechwood ranges from very low to medium. Smoke ﬂavors should be smooth, without harshness. Aroma should strike a balance between malt, hop and smoke.
column17: Hop aroma and ﬂavor is very low to low, derived from noble-type hops.
column19: Fruity esters and diacetyl should not be present

column15: Appearance should be clear. Chill haze should not be present
column16: Medium to medium-high malt aroma and ﬂavor should be present with very low to medium-high beechwood smoke aromas and ﬂavors. Smoke flavors should be smooth, without harshness. Smoke ﬂavor may create a perception of mild sweetness.
column17: Very low
column18: Medium, increasing proportionately with starting gravity.
column19: Fruity esters are usually absent, but if present should be very low. Diacetyl should not be present.

column14: Pale to light amber. The German word “helle” means light-colored, thus Heller Bock is a pale beer.
column15: Appearance should be clear. Chill haze should not be present
column16: Light toasty and/or bready aroma and flavor is often present. Roast or heavy toast/caramel malt aromas and ﬂavors should not be present.
column17: Low to medium-low, derived from noble-type hops.
column19: Fruity esters, if present, should be low. Diacetyl should not be present.

column15: Appearance should be clear. Chill haze should not be present
column16: Traditional Bocks are made with all malt and have high malt character with aromas of toasted or nutty malt, but not caramel. Traditional bocks display high malt sweetness. The malt ﬂavor profile should display a balance of sweetness and toasted or nutty malt, but not caramel.
column17: Very low
column18: Medium, increasing proportionately with starting gravity.
column19: Fruity esters if present should be minimal. Diacetyl should not be present.

column15: Appearance should be clear. Chill haze should not be present
column16: Pronounced aromas and flavors of toasted malted barley. Some caramel and toffee character can contribute to complexity in a secondary role. Dark fruit flavors such as prune and raisin may be present. Malty sweetness is pronounced but should not be cloying. There should be no astringency from roasted malts.
column17: Hop aroma is absent. Hop ﬂavor is low.
column19: Alcoholic strength is high. Fruity esters are commonly perceived at low to moderate levels. Diacetyl should not be present.

column15: Appearance should be clear. Chill haze should not be present
column16: Sweet malt character is very high. Dark fruit flavors such as prune and raisin may be present
column17: Hop aroma and ﬂavor is absent
column19: Alcohol may be present in aroma. Fruity esters may be evident, but not overpowering. Diacetyl should not be present. Alcoholic strength is very high.
column21: This is a stronger version of Doppelbock. Traditionally, these beers were created by freezing a Doppelbock and removing the ice, thus concentrating the alcohol.

column15: Chill haze should not be present
column16: Malt sweetness is very low to low
column17: Not present to very low
column19: Fruity esters are usually absent, but may be present at very low levels. Diacetyl should not be present.
column21: Corn, rice, or other grain or sugar adjuncts are often used. American Lagers are very clean and crisp, and aggressively carbonated.

column15: Chill haze should not be present
column16: Malt sweetness and aroma are very low to low
column17: Very low to low
column19: Fruity esters are usually absent but may be present at very low levels. Diacetyl should not be present.
column21: Corn, rice, or other grain or sugar adjuncts are often used, but all-malt formulations are also made. Contemporary American Lagers typically exhibit increased hop aroma and flavor compared to traditional versions, are clean and crisp, and aggressively carbonated.

column15: Chill haze should not be present
column16: Very low
column17: Absent to very low
column19: Fruity esters are usually absent but may be present at very low levels. Diacetyl should not be present. These beers are characterized by an extremely high degree of attenuation. Final gravity is often less than 1.000 (0.0 ºPlato).
column21: Corn, rice or other grain or sugar adjuncts are often used. These beers are high in carbonation. Flavor attributes typical of beer are usually very low when present. Calories should not exceed 125 per 12-ounce serving. Low carb beers should have a maximum carbohydrate level of 3.0 gm per 12 oz. (355 ml).

column14: Very light to medium amber. The word “Light” refers to light body and reduced calories rather than color.
column15: Chill haze should not be present
column16: Very low but present
column17: Very low to low
column19: Fruity esters are usually absent but may be present at very low levels. Diacetyl should not be present. These beers are characterized by an extremely high degree of attenuation. Final gravity is often less than 1.000 (0.0 ºPlato).
column20: Low to medium-low, often with dry mouthfeel
column21: Corn, rice, or other grain or sugar adjuncts are often used but all-malt formulations are also made. These beers are high in carbonation. Hop attributes, though subtle, are more evident than in traditional American-Style Light Lager. Calories should not exceed 125 per 12-ounce serving. Low carb beers should have a maximum carbohydrate level of 3.0 gm per 12 oz. (355 ml)

column15: Appearance should be clear. Chill haze should not be present
column16: Medium-low to medium
column17: Medium to high, exhibiting attributes typical of noble-type hops
column19: DMS, fruity esters and diacetyl should not be present.
column21: Finish should exhibit low to medium-low body with a clean, crisp malt character evident at low levels. Up to 25% corn and/or rice in the grist should be used. Beers in this category hew to American-style lagers typical of the pre-Prohibition era.

column15: Appearance should be clear. Chill haze should not be present
column16: Medium-low to medium
column17: Medium to high. While traditional versions exhibit attributes typical of noble-type hops, contemporary versions will exhibit attributes typical of a wide range of American hop varieties.
column19: DMS, fruity esters and diacetyl should not be present.
column21: Up to 25% corn and/or rice in the grist should be used. Beers in this category diverge from American-style lagers typical of the pre-Prohibition era by virtue of a wide range of hop aroma and flavor attributes.

column15: Hop haze is allowable. Chill haze should not be present
column16: Medium-low to medium, exhibiting bready, cracker-like or other attributes typical of pale malts
column17: Medium to high with attributes typical of hops of any origin
column18: Medium to high, but not harsh
column19: Fruity esters, DMS and diacetyl should not be present.
column21: This style of beer should exhibit the fresh character of hops.

column15: Appearance should be clear. Chill haze should not be present
column16: Some malt sweetness is present
column17: Not present
column19: Fruity esters and complex alcohol aromas and ﬂavors are acceptable at low levels. Alcohol should not be solvent-like. Diacetyl should not be present.
column21: Beers of this style are varied in character. Some malt liquors are only slightly stronger than American lagers, while others approach bock strength.

column15: Appearance should be clear. Chill haze should not be present
column16: Low to medium-low caramel or toasted malt aromas and ﬂavors should be present
column17: Very low to medium-high
column19: Fruity esters and diacetyl should not be present

column15: Chill haze should not be present
column16: Sweet maltiness should be present, expressed as a light toasted character. Bready or biscuity malt aroma and ﬂavor is acceptable. Low level caramel attributes are acceptable.
column17: Low to medium-low exhibiting herbal, grass-like, spicy, floral or citrus attributes
column19: Fruity esters and diacetyl should not be present
column21: The American version of this classic German beer is distinguished by a more pronounced hop character.

column15: Appearance should be clear. Chill haze should not be present
column16: Low malt aroma and ﬂavor may include low levels of caramel
column17: Very low to low
column18: Very low to low and dissipates quickly.
column19: Carbonation is high. Fruity esters, DMS and diacetyl should not be present.

column15: Opaque. When clarity is perceivable, chill haze should not be present.
column16: Malt sweetness is medium-low to medium-high. Distinctive malt aromas and flavors of caramelized sugars, dark sugars and licorice are present. Roast malt attributes may be present at low levels, but any bitterness or astringency should be in harmony with other flavor aspects.
column17: Very low. Floral hop aroma can complement aromatics.
column19: Due to its alcoholic strength, there may be very low to low levels of complex alcohol aromas and ﬂavors and/or higher levels of fruitiness suggestive of berries, grapes and plums, but not banana. Fruity esters, DMS and diacetyl should not be present.
column21: Baltic Porter is brewed with lager yeast and fermented and lagered cold producing a smooth beer. A low level of oxidation, if harmonious with other flavor components, is acceptable.

column3: Australasian, Latin American or Tropical-Style Light Lager
column15: Chill haze should not be present
column16: Malt sweetness is absent
column17: Not present to very low
column19: Sugar adjuncts are often used to lighten the body and ﬂavor, sometimes contributing to very low to low fruity esters such as apple or pear. Diacetyl should not be present.
column21: Sugar, corn, rice, and other cereal grains or carbohydrates sources are used as adjuncts.

column15: Appearance should be clear. Chill haze should not be present
column16: Residual malt aroma and ﬂavor may be present at low levels
column17: Low
column19: Very low levels of DMS aroma and ﬂavor are acceptable. Fruity esters and diacetyl should not be present.
column21: These beers are often brewed with rice, corn, wheat, or other grains. Sugar adjuncts may also be used.
